physical_appearance:This painting depicts three European men. The man on the most left is dressed in Augustinian friar robes
 with quills and pots of ink beside him. The man in the center is dressed in a white coat and a hat with feathers
 holding a stick
 with a sword at his side. The man on the right is in black and brown attire
 with a red sash around his hip. He is also holding a stick and has a sword at his side. The names of the men in the painting are inscribed below the figures. At the bottom of the painting
 the creator has inscribed a passage in Spanish. There is no creator\u0027s signature inscribed.

sgcool_label_text:The three men in this painting were crucial to the establishment of the Spanish colony in the Philippines
 and the Manila Galleon trade. From left
 they are Friar Andrés de Urdaneta (1498–1568)
 Miguel López de Legazpi (1502–1572)
 and Ferdinand Magellan (1480–1521). \r\nMagellan was a Portuguese-born explorer best known for captaining on behalf of the Spanish Crown the first fleet of ships that circumnavigated the world. Lopez de Legazpi and Urdaneta formed the first European settlement in the Philippines on Cebu in 1565. Friar Urdaneta’s documentation of his voyage was the basis for the Manila-Acapulco Galleon trade route. Spanish ships sailed this route across the Pacific for around 250 years
 carrying luxury goods that created riches for Spain.\r\n\r\n

The man in the center is dressed in a white coat and a hat with feathers, holding a stick, with a sword at his side. The man on the right is in black and brown attire, with a red sash around his hip. metadata.context_1: Foundation of the Spanish colony in the Philippines
metadata.sgcool_label_text:
The three men in this painting were crucial to the establishment of the Spanish colony in the Philippines, and the Manila Galleon trade. From left, they are Friar Andrés de Urdaneta (1498–1568), Miguel López de Legazpi (1502–1572), and Ferdinand Magellan (1480–1521). 
Magellan was a Portuguese-born explorer best known for captaining on behalf of the Spanish Crown the first fleet of ships that circumnavigated the world. Lopez de Legazpi and Urdaneta formed the first European settlement in the Philippines on Cebu in 1565. Friar Urdaneta’s documentation of his voyage was the basis for the Manila-Acapulco Galleon trade route. Spanish ships sailed this route across the Pacific for around 250 years, carrying luxury goods that created riches for Spain.
